@metadata.goal: The student can shade one part to represent a unit fraction

steps.dialogue: Here's a pizza cut into 8 equal slices. The bar below shows the same thing—8 equal parts.
Shade one part to show what fraction one slice represents.

step.dialogue: Check how many parts you shaded. We need exactly 1.

events.name: highlight_single_section
events.description: One section of the bar pulses gently to show the target amount

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_single_section]You're working on it. One slice means one part shaded. Count your shaded sections—we need just 1.

events.name: shade_one_section_animated
events.description: Animated demonstration showing one section being shaded, with counting overlay showing '1 out of 8'

step.dialogue: [event:shade_one_section_animated]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. One slice out of eight means we shade exactly one part. Watch: I'll shade this section right here. That's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]—one part out of eight total. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! One slice out of eight is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction].

@metadata.goal: The student can count the total number of equal parts in a whole

steps.dialogue: Here's a sandwich cut into equal pieces for sharing.
Each person gets [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction] of the sandwich. How many equal parts is the whole sandwich divided into?

prompt.text: Select the total number of equal parts

step.dialogue: Count all the equal parts in the sandwich.

events.name: highlight_all_sections
events.description: All 8 sections of the sandwich pulse sequentially to emphasize counting all parts

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_all_sections]Let's think about this together. The denominator in [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction] tells us how many equal parts make up the whole sandwich.

events.name: count_sections_sequentially
events.description: Animated counting overlay that highlights and numbers each section sequentially from 1 to 8, with numbers appearing above each section

step.dialogue: [event:count_sections_sequentially]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. The bottom number in a fraction tells us the total equal parts. Let's count each section: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. The whole sandwich has 8 equal parts. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! The denominator tells you the total parts in the whole.

@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Maria ate [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction] of a granola bar. Here are three different granola bars.
Which bar shows the whole granola bar before Maria ate any?

prompt.text: Click the bar that shows the whole

step.dialogue: Look at the complete bar. Which one has all its parts?

events.name: pulse_complete
events.description: Bar A pulses to draw attention to its completeness

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_complete]You're working on it. The whole bar needs all 8 parts before Maria ate any. Check which bar is complete.

events.name: count_sections_complete
events.description: Animated counting overlay showing all 8 sections present and complete in Bar A

events.name: highlight_missing_section
events.description: Red outline appears around the missing section in Bar B

events.name: count_sections_incomplete
events.description: Counting overlay shows only 7 sections in Bar C

step.dialogue: [event:count_sections_complete][event:highlight_missing_section][event:count_sections_incomplete]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. The whole bar is the one before Maria ate anything. Bar A has all 8 parts - that's the complete whole. Bar B is missing a piece, and Bar C only has 7 parts. Bar A shows the whole. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. The whole granola bar had 8 equal parts before Maria ate one.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Two friends are sharing pizza. Friend A gets [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] of a pizza. Friend B gets [fraction numerator=1 denominator=5]one fifth[/fraction] of an equal-sized pizza.
Look at the shaded parts. Who gets more pizza?

step.dialogue: Look at the actual size of each shaded piece.

events.name: highlight_shaded_section
events.description: Shaded sections of both pizzas pulse to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_shaded_section]You're working on it. Compare the shaded sections - which piece takes up more space on the pizza?

events.name: measure_section_width
events.description: Animated overlays showing width measurements of both sections

events.name: comparison_bracket
events.description: Visual bracket showing 1/3 is larger than 1/5

step.dialogue: [event:measure_section_width][event:comparison_bracket]Let's work through this together. Look at Friend A's piece - it's 1 out of 3 parts. Now look at Friend B's piece - it's 1 out of 5 parts. When we cut into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. Friend A gets more pizza. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. When the whole is split into fewer parts, each piece is bigger.

@metadata.goal: The student can apply partitioning strategies and recognize patterns with equal parts

steps.dialogue: Check out these three bars. Each one is divided into equal parts.
Look at the pattern: 2 parts, then 6 parts, then 18 parts. What's the rule?
If the pattern continues, how many equal parts would the next bar have?

step.dialogue: Look at how the numbers change from one bar to the next.

events.name: pulse_bar_1
events.description: Bar 1 pulses to highlight starting value of 2

events.name: pulse_bar_2
events.description: Bar 2 pulses to highlight value of 6

events.name: pulse_bar_3
events.description: Bar 3 pulses to highlight value of 18

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_bar_1][event:pulse_bar_2][event:pulse_bar_3]You're working on it. Compare each bar to the one before it. What operation gets you from 2 to 6? From 6 to 18?

events.name: show_multiplication_arrow_1_to_2
events.description: Arrow appears from bar 1 to bar 2 with '× 3' label showing the pattern

events.name: show_multiplication_arrow_2_to_3
events.description: Arrow appears from bar 2 to bar 3 with '× 3' label showing the pattern

events.name: show_next_step
events.description: Arrow extends from bar 3 downward with '× 3 = 54' showing the next value

step.dialogue: [event:show_multiplication_arrow_1_to_2][event:show_multiplication_arrow_2_to_3][event:show_next_step]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Look at the pattern: 2 times 3 equals 6, then 6 times 3 equals 18. Each bar has three times as many parts as the one before. So 18 times 3 equals 54. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: You found it! Each bar has three times as many parts as the one before.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Three students each cut a sandwich into 4 pieces. Let's see how each one did it.
Which sandwiches have pieces that each represent [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]? Pick all that work.

prompt.text: Select all sandwiches with equal fourths

step.dialogue: Check the sizes of the pieces in each sandwich.

events.name: pulse_sections_a
events.description: All four sections of sandwich A pulse to show equal sizing

events.name: pulse_sections_b
events.description: All four sections of sandwich B pulse to show unequal sizing

events.name: pulse_sections_c
events.description: All four sections of sandwich C pulse to show equal sizing

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_a][event:pulse_sections_b][event:pulse_sections_c]Let's think about this together. For [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] to work, all four pieces must be exactly the same size. Look closely at each sandwich.

events.name: measure_sections_equal_a
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections are equal width

events.name: measure_sections_unequal_b
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections

events.name: measure_sections_equal_c
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections are equal width

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_equal_a][event:measure_sections_unequal_b][event:measure_sections_equal_c]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For a piece to be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], all four pieces must be equal. Watch: Sandwich A has equal pieces—each is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. Sandwich B has unequal pieces—this one is bigger, so they can't all be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. Sandwich C has equal pieces—each is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. So A and C work. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. Equal parts can look different, but they all have the same size.
